This is the Luman School. It was in the NE part of Warren Township, Section 12, and the land was sold to the county for $1.00 on May 4, 1888, by Aaron Bliss.

One year, after completing the school year at Yager School, teacher Lloyd Schad was asked to finish the last four weeks of school at Luman. Three other teachers either quit or resigned because of discipline issues.

This school was moved to the school yard, where the Library now stands, and used as a band room at one point. Later, it was moved again, and is part of The Board of Ed.

Certainly not the school year we wanted or planned on with so many challenges, missed events and activities and even more missed friends and supporters of our students and district. But, I'm still proud of all of us- our kids, their parents and my staff. This team has overall handled themselves positively, been supportive of each other and adjusted as well as any group I've seen anywhere. And it's been done because we love our Comets. We value what we do and WHY we do it. Our WHY is strong- it's always about learning of our kids and helping them to be successful academically, artistically, athletically, socially, emotionally and behaviorally.

On what would have been our last day of the 2019-2020 school year, students, know that we will miss you this summer and have missed you the past 3 months. We'll continue to focus on our WHY- you- in everything we do and every decision we make moving forward. Thanks for making us proud! Have a fantastic summer!

#Coleman #growingforthefuture #education #Agriscience #preferreddistrict #arts #academics #athletics #CometPride
